summary: This document is a chain of emails between the prosecution and defense teams in the case of United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell (20 Cr. 330). The correspondence details extensive logistical negotiations for the defense to review physical evidence stored in an FBI warehouse in the Bronx and highly confidential electronic images, and for Maxwell to be present for review at the 500 Pearl Street courthouse. It reveals the volume and sensitive nature of evidence, including thousands of nude/partially nude images seized from Jeffrey Epstein's devices.

persons.name: Christian Everdell
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell from the law firm Cohen & Gresser, coordinating evidence review logistics with the prosecution.

persons.name: Laura Menninger
persons.context: Lead defense attorney and partner at Haddon, Morgan & Foreman, P.C., representing Ghislaine Maxwell and negotiating evidence review terms with the prosecution.

persons.name: Jeff Pagliuca
persons.context: Defense attorney copied on the correspondence, part of Ghislaine Maxwell's legal team.

persons.name: Bobbi C Sternheim
persons.context: Defense attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell, copied on all logistical emails regarding evidence review.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The accused in the case (US v. Maxwell - 20 Cr. 330). The emails discuss arrangements for her to be produced from the MDC to the 500 Pearl Street courthouse to participate in evidence review.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Referred to as the source of seized evidence, including electronic devices, images, and videos from his residences. His 2019 investigations by the FBI are mentioned.

connections.description: Menninger is a lead defense attorney representing Maxwell in the criminal case, as shown in the legal correspondence.
Everdell is part of Maxwell's defense legal team, coordinating evidence review on her behalf.
Evidence in the case, including images and items, was seized from Epstein's residences, linking the two in the underlying investigation.
Both are attorneys on Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team, collaborating on evidence review logistics.

events.title: Scheduled Evidence Review at Bronx Warehouse
events.description: Planned date for defense team (attorney, investigator, paralegal) to review and photograph non-transportable evidence items at the FBI warehouse in the Bronx.

events.title: Scheduled Evidence Review at 500 Pearl Street with Maxwell
events.description: Planned start date for Ghislaine Maxwell to be produced to the 500 Pearl Street courthouse to review evidence, including highly confidential materials, with her defense team. Review was scheduled to occur daily from 9:30am to 4:30pm.

events.title: FBI Searches of Epstein Residences
events.description: The FBI seized electronic devices, servers, laptops, and other physical evidence from Jeffrey Epstein's residences in New York and the U.S. Virgin Islands in 2019.

events.title: Production of Images and Videos
events.description: The government produced images and videos seized from Epstein's devices to the defense, with a cover letter noting that nude/partially nude images were designated 'Highly Confidential' and would be made available for review upon request.

locations: 2350 Lafayette Ave, Bronx, NY (FBI evidence warehouse)
500 Pearl Street, New York, NY (courthouse for evidence review)
1 St. Andrew's Plaza, New York, NY 10007 (Southern District of New York U.S. Attorney's Office)
26 Federal Plaza, New York, NY (FBI office where cash evidence was held)
150 E. 10th Avenue, Denver, CO 80203 (Haddon, Morgan & Foreman law office)
MDC (Metropolitan Detention Center, where Ghislaine Maxwell was held)
keyFacts: The defense sought to review all physical evidence, which included approximately 15-20 boxes of transportable items, plus bulky/fragile items like plaster busts, a stuffed dog, and framed pictures stored at an FBI warehouse in the Bronx.

The prosecution disclosed the existence of approximately 5,507 'Highly Confidential' electronic images and videos, including about 2,100 never-before-produced images from Epstein's devices, about 3,400 previously reviewed images from discs, and about 7 hard-copy nude images from the FBI Florida office's investigation.

Logistical constraints included: only one clean laptop could be provided for reviewing the highly confidential electronic images (due to their obscene nature), electronic devices were not permitted in the FBI warehouse, and the Marshals would produce Maxwell to 500 Pearl Street only until 4:30pm each day.

The defense raised specific issues about evidence items, including shredded paper at FBI HQ, 'missing from assigned box' items, stripped metadata on electronic files, and the format of a 2007 interview recording.

The email chain reveals the extensive and contentious pre-trial process of organizing discovery review, highlighting the massive volume of sensitive evidence and the defense's efforts to ensure Maxwell could participate in her defense.
